Welcome to your first chapter in the AI Textbook Platform! This chapter introduces you to the fundamental concepts of Artificial Intelligence and sets the foundation for your learning journey.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is transforming how we interact with technology and solve complex problems. In this chapter, you'll learn what AI is, its history, key concepts, and real-world applications.

By the end of this chapter, you will: Understand the definition and scope of Artificial Intelligence Learn about the history and evolution of AI Explore different types of AI systems Discover real-world applications of AI Understand the ethical considerations in AI development

This chapter is organized into the following sections: Learning Objectives - What you'll master in this chapter Concepts - Core AI concepts with visual diagrams Hands-On Lab - Build your first AI program Exercises - Practice problems to reinforce learning Quiz - Test your understanding FAQs - Common questions answered
This chapter assumes: Basic programming knowledge (any language) Familiarity with basic mathematics (algebra) Curiosity and willingness to learn!
Reading: 30 minutes Hands-on lab: 45 minutes Exercises: 30 minutes Total: ~2 hours Ready to begin? Start with the Learning Objectives to see what you'll master in this chapter.

Artificial Intelligence (AI) is the simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems. These processes include: Learning: Acquiring information and rules for using it Reasoning: Using rules to reach approximate or definite conclusions Self-correction: Improving performance based on feedback

AI encompasses several related but distinct concepts. Here's how they relate to each other: Key Relationships: AI is the broadest concept - any technique that enables computers to mimic human intelligence Machine Learning (ML) is a subset of AI that learns from data without explicit programming Deep Learning (DL) is a subset of ML that uses neural networks with multiple layers
AI systems can be categorized based on their capabilities:

Definition: AI designed to perform a specific task or set of tasks. Characteristics: Operates within a limited context Cannot transfer knowledge to other domains Most AI systems today are Narrow AI Examples: Virtual assistants (Siri, Alexa) Recommendation systems (Netflix, Amazon) Image recognition systems Chess-playing programs

Definition: AI with human-like intelligence that can understand, learn, and apply knowledge across different domains. Characteristics: Can transfer learning between tasks Possesses common sense reasoning Currently theoretical - not yet achieved Status: Research goal, not yet realized

Definition: AI that surpasses human intelligence in all aspects. Characteristics: Exceeds human cognitive abilities Can improve itself recursively Highly speculative Status: Theoretical concept, subject of debate

Process Breakdown: Input Data: Raw information (text, images, numbers) AI Model: Algorithm that processes the data Processing: Computation and pattern recognition Output: Prediction, classification, or decision Feedback: Used to improve the model (learning)
documents.s: How AI Works: A Simple Model

documents.t: Definition: Algorithms that improve automatically through experience. Types: Supervised Learning: Learning from labeled data Unsupervised Learning: Finding patterns in unlabeled data Reinforcement Learning: Learning through trial and error
Definition: Computing systems inspired by biological neural networks. Structure: Components: Input Layer: Receives data Hidden Layers: Process information Output Layer: Produces results
Definition: Enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language. Applications: Language translation Sentiment analysis Chatbots Text summarization
Disease diagnosis from medical images Drug discovery Personalized treatment plans
Fraud detection Algorithmic trading Credit scoring
Autonomous vehicles Traffic prediction Route optimization
Content recommendations Game AI Music generation
AI systems can perpetuate or amplify human biases present in training data. Example: Facial recognition systems showing lower accuracy for certain demographic groups.
AI systems often require large amounts of personal data. Challenge: Balancing data utility with individual privacy rights.
When AI makes decisions, who is responsible for errors or harm? Question: Should it be the developer, the user, or the AI system itself?
Automation through AI may eliminate certain jobs while creating new ones. Consideration: How do we manage this transition fairly?

In this section, you learned: ‚úÖ The definition and scope of AI ‚úÖ The relationship between AI, ML, and DL ‚úÖ Different types of AI systems ‚úÖ How AI works at a high level ‚úÖ Key AI techniques and their applications ‚úÖ Ethical considerations in AI development Next: Apply what you've learned in the Hands-On Lab where you'll build your first AI program!
Total Estimated Time: 2-3 hours This chapter is designed to be completed in one focused session, though you can break it into smaller segments based on your schedule.
Overview and Learning Objectives: 10 minutes Core Concepts: 35-50 minutes Understanding Physical AI Embodied Intelligence Key Terminology System Architecture
Environment Setup: 20-30 minutes Running First Examples: 20-30 minutes Experimentation: 20-30 minutes
Exercises: 10-15 minutes Quiz: 5-10 minutes FAQ Review: 5 minutes
If you're already familiar with programming and basic robotics concepts: Skim concepts: 30 minutes Complete hands-on lab: 60 minutes Do exercises and quiz: 30 minutes
Recommended for most learners: Read all concepts thoroughly: 60 minutes Complete hands-on lab with experimentation: 90 minutes Complete all exercises and quiz: 30 minutes
For comprehensive understanding: Study all concepts with additional research: 90 minutes Complete hands-on lab with variations: 120 minutes Complete all exercises at all difficulty levels: 60 minutes

Eliminate Distractions: Close unnecessary tabs and applications Take Notes: Write down key concepts and questions Hands-On First: Prioritize the lab over passive reading Ask Questions: Use the AI assistant for clarification

Natural stopping points if you need to pause: ‚úã After completing "Core Concepts" section ‚úã After environment setup in hands-on lab ‚úã After completing the hands-on lab ‚úã After finishing exercises
If local setup is taking too long, switch to cloud instances: AWS EC2 t3.medium: ~$0.04/hour Google Cloud e2-medium: ~$0.03/hour Azure B2s: ~$0.04/hour
Before starting the hands-on lab: # Download required packages in advance pip install -r requirements.txt
While waiting for installations: Read ahead to the next section Review FAQs Watch supplementary videos (if available)

By the end of this chapter, you will: ‚úÖ Understand what Physical AI is and why it matters ‚úÖ Know the key components of embodied intelligence systems ‚úÖ Have a working development environment ‚úÖ Have run your first Physical AI example ‚úÖ Be ready to dive deeper into ROS 2 in Chapter 2 Time Management Tip: Set a timer for each section to stay on track. It's okay to take longer if you're learning thoroughly!
Practice what you've learned with these exercises. They're organized by difficulty level.

Question: Classify each of the following as Narrow AI, General AI, or Super AI: a) A chess-playing program that beats world champions b) A hypothetical AI that can learn any human skill c) A spam email filter d) A virtual assistant like Siri or Alexa e) An AI that surpasses human intelligence in all domains Show Answer Answers: a) Narrow AI - specialized for chess only b) General AI - can transfer learning across domains c) Narrow AI - specific task of filtering spam d) Narrow AI - limited to voice commands and queries e) Super AI - exceeds human capabilities

Question: For each statement, identify whether it describes AI, Machine Learning (ML), or Deep Learning (DL): a) Uses neural networks with multiple layers b) Broad field of making machines intelligent c) Learns from data without explicit programming d) Requires large amounts of data and computing power e) Includes rule-based systems and expert systems Show Answer Answers: a) Deep Learning (DL) b) Artificial Intelligence (AI) c) Machine Learning (ML) d) Deep Learning (DL) e) Artificial Intelligence (AI)
documents.s: Exercise 2: AI vs ML vs DL

documents.t: Question: Match each AI application with its primary technique: Applications: Netflix movie recommendations Self-driving cars Language translation Facial recognition Techniques: A. Computer Vision B. Natural Language Processing C. Reinforcement Learning D. Collaborative Filtering Show Answer Answers: 1-D: Netflix uses collaborative filtering for recommendations 2-C: Self-driving cars use reinforcement learning 3-B: Translation uses NLP 4-A: Facial recognition uses computer vision

Scenario: A company develops an AI hiring system that screens job applications. After deployment, they discover the system rejects more female candidates than male candidates with similar qualifications. Questions: a) What ethical issue does this scenario illustrate? b) What might have caused this bias? c) How could the company address this problem? d) What preventive measures should have been taken? Show Answer Answers: a) Ethical Issue: Algorithmic bias and discrimination b) Possible Causes: Training data reflected historical hiring biases Features correlated with gender (e.g., career gaps) Lack of diverse representation in training data c) Solutions: Audit the training data for bias Retrain with balanced, representative data Implement fairness constraints in the algorithm Add human oversight to the hiring process d) Preventive Measures: Diverse development team Bias testing before deployment Regular audits and monitoring Transparent documentation of data sources

Question: For each scenario, recommend the most appropriate ML approach (Supervised, Unsupervised, or Reinforcement Learning) and explain why: a) Predicting house prices based on historical sales data b) Grouping customers into segments without predefined categories c) Training a robot to navigate a maze d) Classifying emails as spam or not spam e) Discovering patterns in customer purchase behavior Show Answer Answers: a) Supervised Learning - We have labeled data (historical prices) to learn from b) Unsupervised Learning - No predefined categories; algorithm finds natural groupings c) Reinforcement Learning - Robot learns through trial and error with rewards/penalties d) Supervised Learning - We have labeled examples of spam and non-spam emails e) Unsupervised Learning - Discovering hidden patterns without predefined labels

Question: Review this code snippet and answer the questions: from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier # Training data X_train = [[0, 0], [1, 1], [2, 2], [3, 3]] y_train = [0, 0, 1, 1] # Create and train model model = DecisionTreeClassifier() model.fit(X_train, y_train) # Make prediction prediction = model.predict([[1.5, 1.5]]) a) What type of learning is this (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement)? b) How many features does each data point have? c) How many classes are in the output? d) What would you expect the prediction to be for input [1.5, 1.5]? Show Answer Answers: a) Supervised Learning - We have labeled training data (X_train with y_train) b) Two features - Each data point is a 2D coordinate [x, y] c) Two classes - Classes 0 and 1 (binary classification) d) Likely class 0 - The input [1.5, 1.5] is closer to the training points labeled as class 0

Challenge: Design an AI system for a smart home that learns user preferences and automates home settings (temperature, lighting, music). Requirements: Describe the data you would collect Choose appropriate ML techniques Address privacy concerns Explain how the system would learn and adapt Deliverable: Write a 1-page system design document.

Challenge: You're given a dataset of loan applications with the following features: income, credit score, employment history, zip code, and loan approval status. Tasks: a) Identify potential sources of bias in this dataset b) Propose methods to detect bias in a trained model c) Suggest techniques to mitigate identified biases d) Design a fairness evaluation framework

Challenge: Choose one of the following AI breakthroughs and create a 5-minute presentation: AlphaGo defeating world champion Lee Sedol GPT-3 and large language models DALL-E and image generation AlphaFold solving protein folding Include: Technical approach used Significance of the breakthrough Ethical implications Future applications

Detailed solutions for advanced exercises are available in the course discussion forum. We encourage you to: Attempt the exercises independently first Compare your answers with peers Discuss different approaches Ask questions in the forum Completed the exercises? Test your knowledge with the Quiz!
Quick answers to common questions about AI fundamentals.

Answer: AI (Artificial Intelligence) is the broader concept of machines being able to carry out tasks in a way that we would consider "smart." Machine Learning is a subset of AI that focuses on the idea that machines can learn from data without being explicitly programmed for every scenario. Analogy: Think of AI as the entire field of making computers intelligent, and ML as one specific approach to achieving that intelligence.
documents.s: What's the difference between AI and Machine Learning?

documents.t: Answer: Deep Learning is actually a type of Machine Learning, not a replacement for it. Deep Learning excels with large datasets and complex patterns (like image recognition), but traditional ML algorithms can be more efficient and interpretable for simpler problems with smaller datasets. When to use each: Deep Learning: Large datasets, complex patterns, images, audio, text Traditional ML: Smaller datasets, need for interpretability, limited computing resources
documents.s: Is Deep Learning better than Machine Learning?

documents.t: Answer: While a strong foundation in mathematics (especially linear algebra, calculus, and statistics) is helpful for understanding AI deeply, you can start building AI applications with basic math knowledge. Many modern frameworks and libraries abstract away complex mathematical operations. Recommended path: Start with high-level frameworks (scikit-learn, TensorFlow) Learn math concepts as you encounter them Deepen mathematical understanding over time
documents.s: Do I need to be a math expert to work with AI?

documents.t: Answer: No, General AI (also called Artificial General Intelligence or AGI) has not been achieved. All current AI systems are Narrow AI, designed for specific tasks. General AI would require human-like intelligence that can transfer learning across different domains, which remains a research goal. Current status: Active research area with no consensus on timeline for achievement.

Answer: Automation follows predefined rules to perform tasks, while AI can learn and adapt based on data. Traditional automation is rule-based ("if X, then Y"), whereas AI can handle ambiguity and make decisions in novel situations. Example: Automation: A thermostat that turns on heating when temperature drops below 20¬∞C AI: A smart thermostat that learns your schedule and preferences to optimize temperature automatically
documents.s: What's the difference between AI and automation?

documents.t: Answer: AI can generate novel outputs (art, music, text) that appear creative, but whether this constitutes true creativity is debated. AI systems like DALL-E and GPT-3 can produce impressive creative works, but they're based on patterns learned from training data rather than genuine understanding or consciousness. Current capabilities: AI can assist human creativity and generate creative outputs, but the nature of machine "creativity" differs from human creativity.

Answer: It depends on the problem complexity and the algorithm used: Simple problems: Hundreds to thousands of examples Complex problems (like image recognition): Millions of examples Transfer learning: Can work with much less data by leveraging pre-trained models Rule of thumb: Start with whatever data you have, evaluate performance, and collect more if needed.
documents.s: How much data do I need to train an AI model?

documents.t: Answer: Training data: Used to teach the model patterns and relationships Testing data: Used to evaluate how well the model performs on unseen data Why separate them?: To ensure the model generalizes well and doesn't just memorize the training data (overfitting). Typical split: 70-80% training, 20-30% testing (sometimes with a validation set in between).
documents.s: What's the difference between training and testing data?

documents.t: Answer: Training time varies dramatically: Simple models: Seconds to minutes Complex deep learning models: Hours to days (or even weeks for very large models) Factors affecting training time: Dataset size, model complexity, hardware (GPUs vs CPUs) Example: Training a simple spam classifier might take seconds, while training a large language model like GPT-3 took weeks on specialized hardware.
documents.s: How long does it take to train an AI model?

documents.t: Answer: Yes! AI models can run offline once they're trained. The training process might require cloud resources, but the trained model can be deployed on local devices (edge AI). Examples of offline AI: Smartphone face recognition Voice assistants (with limited functionality) Autonomous vehicles Industrial robots
documents.s: Can AI work without internet connectivity?

documents.t: Answer: Costs vary widely: Using pre-built AI services: Can be very affordable (pay-per-use) Training custom models: Can be expensive (computing resources, data collection, expertise) Open-source tools: Free to use, but require technical expertise Cost factors: Data collection, computing resources, development time, maintenance.

Answer: Accuracy varies by application and implementation: High accuracy (>95%): Image classification, speech recognition (in controlled environments) Moderate accuracy (70-90%): Sentiment analysis, recommendation systems Lower accuracy: Complex reasoning, understanding context, handling edge cases Important: Even high accuracy doesn't mean perfection. A 95% accurate medical diagnosis system still makes errors 5% of the time.

Answer: Yes, AI systems can exhibit bias in several ways: Training data bias: If training data reflects societal biases, the AI will learn them Selection bias: Unrepresentative training data Algorithmic bias: The algorithm itself may favor certain outcomes Mitigation strategies: Diverse training data, bias testing, fairness constraints, human oversight.

Answer: AI poses both risks and benefits: Current risks: Bias and discrimination Privacy violations Job displacement Misuse (deepfakes, surveillance) Speculative risks: Loss of control over advanced AI systems Existential risk from superintelligent AI (highly debated) Key point: The danger often comes from how AI is used, not the technology itself.

Answer: This is an active area of legal and ethical debate. Responsibility typically falls on: Developers: For design flaws or inadequate testing Deployers: For inappropriate use or lack of oversight Users: For misuse or ignoring limitations Current status: Legal frameworks are still evolving to address AI accountability.
documents.s: Who is responsible when AI makes a mistake?

documents.t: Answer: Python is the most popular choice for AI/ML because: Extensive libraries (TensorFlow, PyTorch, scikit-learn) Large community and resources Easy to learn and read Industry standard Alternatives: R (for statistics), Julia (for performance), JavaScript (for web-based AI).
documents.s: What programming language should I learn for AI?

documents.t: Answer: A structured approach works best: Foundations: Learn programming (Python) and basic math Theory: Understand ML concepts and algorithms Practice: Build projects and experiment Specialize: Focus on areas that interest you (NLP, computer vision, etc.) Stay current: Follow research, take courses, join communities Resources: Online courses (Coursera, edX), books, tutorials, and hands-on projects.
documents.s: What's the best way to learn AI?

documents.t: Answer: No! You can start learning AI with: Your current computer: For learning concepts and small projects Free cloud resources: Google Colab, Kaggle Notebooks (with free GPU access) Pre-trained models: Use existing models without training from scratch When you need more: As you advance to larger projects, you might need GPUs, but many cloud options are affordable.
documents.s: Do I need expensive hardware to learn AI?

documents.t: If your question isn't answered here: Review the Concepts section for detailed explanations Try the Hands-On Lab for practical experience Check the course discussion forum Ask your instructor or peers Ready for the next chapter? You've completed Chapter 1! Proceed to Chapter 2 to continue your AI learning journey.

Duration: 45 minutes Difficulty: Beginner Prerequisites: Basic Python knowledge In this lab, you'll build a simple AI program that uses machine learning to classify text sentiment (positive or negative). This hands-on exercise will help you understand the basic workflow of an AI project.

A sentiment analysis program that can determine whether a text review is positive or negative. Example: Input: "This product is amazing!" ‚Üí Output: Positive Input: "Terrible experience, very disappointed." ‚Üí Output: Negative
First, ensure you have Python 3.8+ installed. Then install the required libraries: pip install scikit-learn numpy

Create a new file called sentiment_analyzer.py: # sentiment_analyzer.py import numpy as np from sklearn.feature_extraction.text import CountVectorizer from sklearn.naive_bayes import MultinomialNB from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split # Sample training data training_data = [ ("I love this product", "positive"), ("This is amazing", "positive"), ("Great quality", "positive"), ("Excellent service", "positive"), ("Best purchase ever", "positive"), ("Terrible experience", "negative"), ("Very disappointed", "negative"), ("Waste of money", "negative"), ("Poor quality", "negative"), ("Would not recommend", "negative"), ] # Separate features and labels texts = [text for text, label in training_data] labels = [label for text, label in training_data] # Create feature vectors vectorizer = CountVectorizer() X = vectorizer.fit_transform(texts) # Train the model classifier = MultinomialNB() classifier.fit(X, labels) # Function to predict sentiment def predict_sentiment(text): text_vector = vectorizer.transform([text]) prediction = classifier.predict(text_vector) return prediction[0] # Test the model if __name__ == "__main__": test_texts = [ "This is wonderful", "I hate this", "Pretty good product", "Awful experience" ] print("Sentiment Analysis Results:") print("-" * 40) for text in test_texts: sentiment = predict_sentiment(text) print(f"Text: '{text}'") print(f"Sentiment: {sentiment}") print()

Execute the program: python sentiment_analyzer.py Expected Output: Sentiment Analysis Results: ---------------------------------------- Text: 'This is wonderful' Sentiment: positive Text: 'I hate this' Sentiment: negative Text: 'Pretty good product' Sentiment: positive Text: 'Awful experience' Sentiment: negative

training_data = [ ("I love this product", "positive"), ("Terrible experience", "negative"), # ... more examples ] What's happening: We create labeled training data - text paired with its sentiment label.
vectorizer = CountVectorizer() X = vectorizer.fit_transform(texts) What's happening: The CountVectorizer converts text into numerical features (word counts) that the ML algorithm can process.
classifier = MultinomialNB() classifier.fit(X, labels) What's happening: We use a Naive Bayes classifier to learn patterns from the training data.

def predict_sentiment(text): text_vector = vectorizer.transform([text]) prediction = classifier.predict(text_vector) return prediction[0] What's happening: New text is converted to features and fed to the trained model for prediction.
Add 10 more training examples (5 positive, 5 negative) to improve accuracy. Hint: Include diverse vocabulary and sentence structures.
Modify the program to classify three sentiments: positive, negative, and neutral. Steps: Add neutral examples to training data Update the model to handle three classes Test with neutral sentences
Modify the predict_sentiment function to return both the prediction and confidence score. Hint: Use classifier.predict_proba() instead of predict().
Error: ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'sklearn' Solution: Install scikit-learn: pip install scikit-learn
Problem: Model makes incorrect predictions Solutions: Add more training data Use more diverse vocabulary Try different algorithms (e.g., Logistic Regression)
Problem: Model struggles with words not in training data Solution: Add more training examples or use pre-trained word embeddings.

Congratulations! You've built your first AI program. You learned: ‚úÖ How to prepare training data for ML ‚úÖ How to convert text to numerical features ‚úÖ How to train a classification model ‚úÖ How to make predictions with your model

Complete the Exercises to reinforce your learning Try the challenges above to extend your program Experiment with different ML algorithms Questions? Check the FAQs for common questions about this lab.
This chapter can be completed using different hardware tiers based on your budget and learning goals. All core concepts can be learned using the Minimum Tier (cloud-based).

Feature Minimum Recommended Premium Cost $0-5/month $1,500-2,500 $5,000-15,000 Setup Time 15 minutes 2-4 hours 1-2 days Portability High (cloud) Medium Low Real Hardware No Partial Yes Learning Completeness 100% 100% 100% + Physical
Perfect for: Learning concepts, running simulations, completing all labs

Computer: Any modern laptop/desktop OS: Windows 10+, macOS 11+, or Linux RAM: 8GB minimum Storage: 10GB free space Internet: 10 Mbps+ stable connection Cloud Instance: AWS, GCP, or Azure Instance Type: t3.medium (AWS) or equivalent vCPUs: 2 RAM: 4GB Storage: 30GB SSD Estimated Cost: $0.04/hour (~$30/month if running 24/7, or $5/month for 5 hours/week)

AWS EC2 Setup‚Äã # 1. Launch EC2 instance Instance Type: t3.medium AMI: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS Storage: 30GB gp3 Security Group: Allow SSH (port 22) # 2. Connect via SSH ssh -i your-key.pem ubuntu@your-instance-ip # 3. Install dependencies sudo apt update sudo apt install -y python3-pip python3-venv pip3 install numpy matplotlib Google Cloud Setup‚Äã # 1. Create Compute Engine instance Machine Type: e2-medium Boot Disk: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS, 30GB Firewall: Allow HTTP/HTTPS # 2. Connect via SSH (browser-based) # Click "SSH" button in console # 3. Install dependencies sudo apt update sudo apt install -y python3-pip pip3 install numpy matplotlib
‚úÖ No hardware investment ‚úÖ Quick setup ‚úÖ Access from anywhere ‚úÖ Easy to reset/restart ‚úÖ Pay only for what you use
‚ùå No physical robot interaction ‚ùå Requires internet connection ‚ùå Ongoing costs (though minimal)
Perfect for: Serious learners, developers, those wanting local control

Development Computer‚Äã CPU: Intel i5/i7 or AMD Ryzen 5/7 (8+ cores recommended) RAM: 16GB minimum, 32GB recommended GPU: NVIDIA RTX 4060 Ti / 4070 / 4070 Ti VRAM: 8GB minimum, 12GB+ recommended CUDA Compute Capability: 7.5+ Storage: 256GB SSD minimum, 512GB+ recommended OS: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS (native or dual-boot) Edge Computing Device‚Äã NVIDIA Jetson Orin Nano (8GB) CPU: 6-core ARM Cortex-A78AE GPU: 1024-core NVIDIA Ampere RAM: 8GB Storage: 64GB eMMC + microSD Price: ~$499 OR NVIDIA Jetson Orin NX (16GB) CPU: 8-core ARM Cortex-A78AE GPU: 1024-core NVIDIA Ampere RAM: 16GB Storage: 64GB eMMC Price: ~$699
Development PC: $1,000-1,800 Jetson Device: $500-700 Accessories: $100-200 Total: $1,600-2,700

Ubuntu 22.04 Installation‚Äã # 1. Download Ubuntu 22.04 LTS # https://ubuntu.com/download/desktop # 2. Create bootable USB # Use Rufus (Windows) or Etcher (macOS/Linux) # 3. Install Ubuntu # Follow installation wizard # Choose "Install alongside Windows" for dual-boot # 4. Post-installation setup sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y sudo apt install -y build-essential git python3-pip NVIDIA Driver Installation‚Äã # Install NVIDIA drivers sudo ubuntu-drivers autoinstall sudo reboot # Verify installation nvidia-smi Jetson Orin Setup‚Äã # 1. Flash JetPack 5.1+ using NVIDIA SDK Manager # https://developer.nvidia.com/sdk-manager # 2. Initial setup on Jetson sudo apt update sudo apt install -y python3-pip pip3 install jetson-stats # 3. Verify installation jtop # Monitor Jetson resources
‚úÖ No ongoing cloud costs ‚úÖ Faster development cycle ‚úÖ Offline capability ‚úÖ Real edge computing experience ‚úÖ GPU acceleration for simulations
‚ùå Higher upfront cost ‚ùå Requires technical setup ‚ùå Still no physical robot
Perfect for: Advanced learners, researchers, those building real robots

All Recommended Tier Components PLUS:‚Äã High-End Development Workstation‚Äã CPU: Intel i9 or AMD Ryzen 9 (16+ cores) RAM: 64GB GPU: NVIDIA RTX 4090 VRAM: 24GB CUDA Compute Capability: 8.9 Storage: 1TB NVMe SSD OS: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS Physical Robot Platform‚Äã Choose one based on your focus: For Manipulation: Universal Robots UR5e (~$35,000) Franka Emika Panda (~$25,000) Kinova Gen3 (~$40,000) For Humanoid Robotics: Unitree G1 (~$16,000) Height: 127cm Weight: 35kg DOF: 23-43 (depending on configuration) Payload: 2kg per arm Unitree H1 (~$90,000) Height: 180cm Weight: 47kg DOF: 25 Walking speed: 3.3 m/s For Mobile Robotics: TurtleBot 4 (~$1,500) Clearpath Jackal (~$20,000) Additional Hardware‚Äã Cameras: Intel RealSense D435i (~$300) LiDAR: RPLiDAR A1 ($100) or Velodyne VLP-16 ($4,000) Force/Torque Sensors: ATI Mini40 (~$3,000) Grippers: Robotiq 2F-85 (~$10,000)
Workstation: $3,000-5,000 Jetson Orin NX: $700 Robot Platform: $1,500-90,000 Sensors & Accessories: $500-10,000 Total: $5,700-105,700
Dedicated workspace (10+ square meters) Safety equipment (emergency stops, barriers) Power supply (standard 110V/220V) Network infrastructure Insurance (for high-value robots)
‚úÖ Complete Physical AI experience ‚úÖ Real-world testing ‚úÖ Hardware-software integration ‚úÖ Research-grade capabilities ‚úÖ Portfolio-building projects

For this chapter specifically, you only need:
‚úÖ Cloud instance (t3.medium or equivalent) ‚úÖ Python 3.11+ ‚úÖ 2GB RAM available ‚úÖ Internet connection
Same as Recommended (physical hardware not needed for Chapter 1)

Use Free Tiers: AWS, GCP, and Azure offer free tiers for new users Stop Instances: Stop cloud instances when not in use Spot Instances: Use spot/preemptible instances for 60-90% savings Student Discounts: Many cloud providers offer student credits Open Source: Use open-source tools and simulators Community Resources: Join robotics communities for shared resources Next: Review the Resources section for additional learning materials and community support.
By the end of this chapter, you will be able to:

Objective: Explain what Artificial Intelligence is and distinguish it from related fields like Machine Learning and Deep Learning. Success Criteria: You can provide a clear definition of AI and explain the relationship between AI, ML, and DL using concrete examples.

Objective: Classify AI systems into categories (Narrow AI, General AI, Super AI) and provide examples of each. Success Criteria: You can categorize real-world AI applications into the appropriate AI type and explain the differences between them.

Objective: Trace the major milestones in AI development from the 1950s to present day. Success Criteria: You can identify at least 5 key events in AI history and explain their significance to the field's evolution.

Objective: Evaluate how AI is applied in different industries (healthcare, finance, transportation, etc.). Success Criteria: You can describe at least 3 real-world AI applications and explain the AI techniques they use.

Objective: Identify ethical challenges in AI development and deployment, including bias, privacy, and accountability. Success Criteria: You can articulate at least 3 ethical concerns in AI and propose approaches to address them.

These learning objectives are designed using Bloom's Taxonomy to ensure you develop both knowledge and critical thinking skills: Remember: Define, identify, describe Understand: Explain, classify, trace Apply: Demonstrate, implement (in the hands-on lab) Analyze: Evaluate, compare (in exercises) As you progress through the chapter, refer back to these objectives to track your learning progress. Each section is designed to help you achieve these goals. Next: Proceed to Concepts to start learning the core ideas of AI.
Before starting this chapter, you should have:

Python 3.x: Basic understanding of Python syntax, functions, and object-oriented programming Command Line: Familiarity with terminal/command prompt operations Git: Basic version control concepts (clone, commit, push)
Linear Algebra: Basic understanding of vectors and matrices Geometry: 3D coordinate systems and transformations
Operating System: Ubuntu 22.04 LTS (recommended) or Windows with WSL2 Text Editor/IDE: VS Code, PyCharm, or similar
Basic understanding of robotics concepts Familiarity with ROS (Robot Operating System) Experience with simulation environments Knowledge of machine learning fundamentals
Modern web browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) Stable internet connection (10 Mbps+) AWS/GCP/Azure account for cloud instances
Ubuntu 22.04 LTS 16GB RAM 50GB free disk space Mid-range GPU (optional for simulation)
All recommended requirements Physical robot platform (optional) Edge computing device (Jetson Nano/Orin)
Install Python 3.11+ python3 --version # Should be 3.11 or higher Verify Git Installation git --version Create Working Directory mkdir ~/robotics-learning cd ~/robotics-learning

If you're missing any prerequisites, don't worry! We'll guide you through the basics as we go. The hands-on labs include detailed setup instructions. Ready? Let's move on to understanding the estimated time commitment for this chapter.
Test your understanding of Chapter 1 concepts with this quiz. Try to answer without looking back at the chapter first!

What is the primary difference between Narrow AI and General AI? A) Narrow AI is less powerful than General AI B) Narrow AI is designed for specific tasks, while General AI can handle any intellectual task C) Narrow AI uses neural networks, while General AI uses rule-based systems D) Narrow AI is theoretical, while General AI exists today Show Answer Answer: B Narrow AI (Weak AI) is designed to perform specific tasks within a limited context, while General AI (Strong AI) would have human-like intelligence capable of understanding, learning, and applying knowledge across different domains. Most AI systems today are Narrow AI.

Which of the following is NOT a type of Machine Learning? A) Supervised Learning B) Unsupervised Learning C) Reinforcement Learning D) Deterministic Learning Show Answer Answer: D The three main types of Machine Learning are: Supervised Learning (learning from labeled data) Unsupervised Learning (finding patterns in unlabeled data) Reinforcement Learning (learning through trial and error) "Deterministic Learning" is not a recognized ML category.

What is the relationship between AI, Machine Learning, and Deep Learning? A) They are three separate, unrelated fields B) Deep Learning ‚äÇ Machine Learning ‚äÇ AI C) AI ‚äÇ Machine Learning ‚äÇ Deep Learning D) Machine Learning and Deep Learning are the same thing Show Answer Answer: B Deep Learning is a subset of Machine Learning, which is a subset of AI: AI is the broadest concept (any technique for machine intelligence) Machine Learning is a subset of AI (learning from data) Deep Learning is a subset of ML (using multi-layer neural networks)

Which AI technique would be most appropriate for grouping customers into segments without predefined categories? A) Supervised Learning B) Unsupervised Learning C) Reinforcement Learning D) Transfer Learning Show Answer Answer: B Unsupervised Learning is used when you want to find patterns or groupings in data without predefined labels or categories. Clustering algorithms (a type of unsupervised learning) are perfect for customer segmentation.

What is a key ethical concern in AI development? A) AI systems are too expensive to develop B) AI can perpetuate or amplify biases present in training data C) AI requires too much electricity D) AI is too difficult to understand Show Answer Answer: B Bias in AI is a major ethical concern. AI systems can perpetuate or amplify human biases present in training data, leading to unfair or discriminatory outcomes. This is particularly problematic in applications like hiring, lending, and criminal justice.

Statement: Neural networks are inspired by the structure of the human brain. Show Answer Answer: True Neural networks are computing systems inspired by biological neural networks in the human brain. They consist of interconnected nodes (neurons) organized in layers that process information.

Statement: All AI systems today are examples of General AI. Show Answer Answer: False Almost all AI systems today are Narrow AI, designed for specific tasks. General AI (human-like intelligence across all domains) has not yet been achieved and remains a research goal.

Statement: Supervised learning requires labeled training data. Show Answer Answer: True Supervised learning algorithms learn from labeled training data, where each example is paired with the correct output. The algorithm learns to map inputs to outputs based on these examples.

Question: Explain the difference between Supervised Learning and Reinforcement Learning in 2-3 sentences. Show Answer Sample Answer: Supervised Learning learns from labeled training data where the correct outputs are provided, making it suitable for tasks like classification and regression. Reinforcement Learning learns through trial and error by interacting with an environment and receiving rewards or penalties, making it ideal for sequential decision-making tasks like game playing or robotics. The key difference is that supervised learning has explicit correct answers, while reinforcement learning discovers optimal behavior through exploration.

Question: Name three real-world applications of AI and identify which AI technique each primarily uses. Show Answer Sample Answer: Netflix Recommendations - Uses collaborative filtering and machine learning to suggest movies based on viewing history Self-Driving Cars - Uses computer vision for object detection and reinforcement learning for navigation decisions Google Translate - Uses natural language processing and deep learning (neural machine translation) to translate between languages

9-10 correct: Excellent! You have a strong understanding of AI fundamentals 7-8 correct: Good job! Review the concepts you missed 5-6 correct: Fair understanding. Revisit the chapter sections for topics you struggled with Below 5: Review the entire chapter and try the quiz again

After completing the quiz: Review any questions you got wrong Revisit the relevant chapter sections Check the FAQs for additional clarification Move on to Chapter 2 when you're ready! Need more practice? Try the Exercises for hands-on problem-solving.

This chapter introduces the architecture of ROS 2 (Robot Operating System 2), covering the fundamental concepts, communication patterns, and design principles that make ROS 2 the leading framework for robotics development.

ROS 2 architecture and design principles DDS (Data Distribution Service) middleware Nodes, topics, services, and actions Quality of Service (QoS) policies ROS 2 vs ROS 1 differences Real-time capabilities
Completed Chapter 1: Introduction to Physical AI Basic understanding of distributed systems Python or C++ programming knowledge

Module 1: ROS 2 Fundamentals (Weeks 1-5) Status: üöß Content in development This chapter is currently being developed. Check back soon for complete content including: Detailed concepts and diagrams Hands-on labs with ROS 2 Code examples Exercises and quizzes Next Chapter: Chapter 3: ROS 2 Workspace Setup
Total Estimated Time: 3-4 hours This chapter covers the foundational architecture of ROS 2, which is essential for all subsequent chapters. Plan for a focused learning session.

ROS 2 Architecture Overview: 15-20 minutes Layered architecture DDS middleware layer ROS 2 vs ROS 1 comparison Communication Patterns: 25-35 minutes Topics (publish-subscribe) Services (request-response) Actions (long-running tasks) Parameters Quality of Service (QoS): 20-35 minutes QoS policies explained Reliability and durability History and lifespan Practical QoS selection

Environment Setup: 15-20 minutes Workspace configuration Package creation Dependencies installation Creating Nodes: 30-40 minutes Simple publisher node Simple subscriber node Testing communication Services and Actions: 30-40 minutes Service server and client Action server and client Testing patterns QoS Configuration: 15-20 minutes Experimenting with QoS settings Debugging compatibility issues

Exercises: 20-30 minutes Beginner: Simple pub-sub system Intermediate: Multi-node communication Advanced: Custom QoS configuration Quiz: 10-15 minutes Architecture concepts Communication patterns QoS understanding

For those with prior ROS 1 experience or distributed systems knowledge: Skim architecture overview: 30 minutes Focus on ROS 2-specific features (DDS, QoS): 30 minutes Complete hands-on lab: 90 minutes Do exercises and quiz: 30 minutes
Recommended for most learners: Read all concepts thoroughly: 90 minutes Complete hands-on lab with experimentation: 120 minutes Complete all exercises: 30 minutes

For comprehensive mastery: Study all concepts with additional research: 120 minutes Complete hands-on lab with variations: 150 minutes Complete all exercises at all difficulty levels: 60 minutes Explore DDS internals and advanced QoS: 30 minutes

Hands-On First Approach Read architecture overview (15 min) Jump to hands-on lab immediately Return to concepts as needed This works well for practical learners Parallel Learning While code is building/running: Read ahead to next section Review QoS documentation Watch supplementary videos Active Experimentation Don't just copy code examples Modify parameters and observe changes Break things intentionally to understand errors This deepens understanding significantly

Natural stopping points if you need to pause: ‚úã After completing "Core Concepts" section ‚úã After creating your first publisher-subscriber pair ‚úã After completing services section ‚úã After finishing the hands-on lab ‚úã After completing exercises

By the end of this chapter, you will: ‚úÖ Understand ROS 2's layered architecture ‚úÖ Know when to use topics, services, or actions ‚úÖ Configure QoS policies appropriately ‚úÖ Create multi-node ROS 2 systems ‚úÖ Debug communication issues ‚úÖ Be ready for Chapter 3: ROS 2 Workspace
Close unnecessary applications Disable notifications Use Pomodoro technique (25 min focus, 5 min break)
Note which sections take longer than expected Identify areas needing more practice Adjust pace for remaining chapters

This section provides executable code examples to help you understand Physical AI concepts through practical implementation.

A simple Python script to verify your environment setup. #!/usr/bin/env python3 """ Hello Physical AI - Environment Verification This script verifies your Python environment is ready for Physical AI development. """ import sys import platform def check_environment(): """Check and display environment information.""" print("=" * 50) print("Physical AI Environment Check") print("=" * 50) # Python version print(f"
‚úì Python Version: {sys.version}") print(f"‚úì Platform: {platform.system()} {platform.release()}") print(f"‚úì Architecture: {platform.machine()}") # Check required modules required_modules = ['numpy', 'matplotlib'] print("
Checking required modules:") for module in required_modules: try: __import__(module) print(f" ‚úì {module}: installed") except ImportError: print(f" ‚úó {module}: NOT installed") print("
" + "=" * 50) print("Environment check complete!") print("=" * 50) if __name__ == "__main__": check_environment() Expected Output: ================================================== Physical AI Environment Check ================================================== ‚úì Python Version: 3.11.x ‚úì Platform: Linux 5.15.x ‚úì Architecture: x86_64 Checking required modules: ‚úì numpy: installed ‚úì matplotlib: installed ================================================== Environment check complete! ================================================== How to Run: python3 hello_physical_ai.py

Understanding how robots represent their state in Physical AI systems. #!/usr/bin/env python3 """ Robot State Representation Demonstrates how to represent and update robot state in Physical AI. """ import numpy as np from dataclasses import dataclass from typing import Tuple @dataclass class RobotState: """Represents the state of a simple mobile robot.""" position: np.ndarray # [x, y] in meters orientation: float # theta in radians velocity: float # linear velocity in m/s angular_velocity: float # angular velocity in rad/s def __str__(self): return (f"Position: ({self.position[0]:.2f}, {self.position[1]:.2f}) m
" f"Orientation: {np.degrees(self.orientation):.2f}¬∞
" f"Velocity: {self.velocity:.2f} m/s
" f"Angular Velocity: {self.angular_velocity:.2f} rad/s") def update_state(state: RobotState, dt: float) -> RobotState: """ Update robot state using simple kinematic model. Args: state: Current robot state dt: Time step in seconds Returns: Updated robot state """ # Update orientation new_orientation = state.orientation + state.angular_velocity * dt # Update position based on velocity and orientation dx = state.velocity * np.cos(state.orientation) * dt dy = state.velocity * np.sin(state.orientation) * dt new_position = state.position + np.array([dx, dy]) return RobotState( position=new_position, orientation=new_orientation, velocity=state.velocity, angular_velocity=state.angular_velocity ) def simulate_robot_motion(): """Simulate simple robot motion over time.""" # Initial state: robot at origin, facing east, moving forward state = RobotState( position=np.array([0.0, 0.0]), orientation=0.0, # 0 radians = facing east velocity=1.0, # 1 m/s forward angular_velocity=0.1 # 0.1 rad/s turning left ) print("Initial State:") print(state) print("
" + "=" * 50 + "
") # Simulate for 5 seconds with 0.5 second time steps dt = 0.5 total_time = 5.0 steps = int(total_time / dt) for step in range(1, steps + 1): state = update_state(state, dt) print(f"After {step * dt:.1f} seconds:") print(state) print("
" + "-" * 50 + "
") if __name__ == "__main__": simulate_robot_motion() Expected Output: Initial State: Position: (0.00, 0.00) m Orientation: 0.00¬∞ Velocity: 1.00 m/s Angular Velocity: 0.10 rad/s ================================================== After 0.5 seconds: Position: (0.50, 0.00) m Orientation: 2.87¬∞ Velocity: 1.00 m/s Angular Velocity: 0.10 rad/s -------------------------------------------------- ...

Processing sensor data is fundamental to Physical AI systems. #!/usr/bin/env python3 """ Sensor Data Processing Demonstrates basic sensor data filtering and processing for Physical AI. """ import numpy as np import matplotlib.pyplot as plt class SimpleSensor: """Simulates a noisy distance sensor.""" def __init__(self, true_distance: float, noise_std: float = 0.1): """ Initialize sensor. Args: true_distance: Actual distance to object in meters noise_std: Standard deviation of sensor noise """ self.true_distance = true_distance self.noise_std = noise_std def read(self) -> float: """Read sensor with added Gaussian noise.""" noise = np.random.normal(0, self.noise_std) return self.true_distance + noise class MovingAverageFilter: """Simple moving average filter for sensor data.""" def __init__(self, window_size: int = 5): """ Initialize filter. Args: window_size: Number of samples to average """ self.window_size = window_size self.buffer = [] def update(self, value: float) -> float: """ Add new value and return filtered result. Args: value: New sensor reading Returns: Filtered value """ self.buffer.append(value) if len(self.buffer) > self.window_size: self.buffer.pop(0) return np.mean(self.buffer) def demonstrate_filtering(): """Demonstrate sensor noise filtering.""" # Create sensor measuring 2.0 meters with noise sensor = SimpleSensor(true_distance=2.0, noise_std=0.2) filter = MovingAverageFilter(window_size=10) # Collect data num_samples = 100 raw_readings = [] filtered_readings = [] for _ in range(num_samples): raw = sensor.read() filtered = filter.update(raw) raw_readings.append(raw) filtered_readings.append(filtered) # Display statistics print("Sensor Data Analysis") print("=" * 50) print(f"True Distance: {sensor.true_distance:.2f} m") print(f"
Raw Readings:") print(f" Mean: {np.mean(raw_readings):.3f} m") print(f" Std Dev: {np.std(raw_readings):.3f} m") print(f"
Filtered Readings:") print(f" Mean: {np.mean(filtered_readings):.3f} m") print(f" Std Dev: {np.std(filtered_readings):.3f} m") print(f"
Noise Reduction: {(1 - np.std(filtered_readings)/np.std(raw_readings))*100:.1f}%") # Plot results (optional - requires matplotlib) try: plt.figure(figsize=(10, 6)) plt.plot(raw_readings, 'b-', alpha=0.5, label='Raw Sensor Data') plt.plot(filtered_readings, 'r-', linewidth=2, label='Filtered Data') plt.axhline(y=sensor.true_distance, color='g', linestyle='--', label='True Distance') plt.xlabel('Sample Number') plt.ylabel('Distance (m)') plt.title('Sensor Data Filtering for Physical AI') plt.legend() plt.grid(True, alpha=0.3) plt.savefig('sensor_filtering.png') print("
‚úì Plot saved as 'sensor_filtering.png'") except ImportError: print("
(matplotlib not available - skipping plot)") if __name__ == "__main__": demonstrate_filtering() Expected Output: Sensor Data Analysis ================================================== True Distance: 2.00 m Raw Readings: Mean: 2.003 m Std Dev: 0.198 m Filtered Readings: Mean: 2.001 m Std Dev: 0.089 m Noise Reduction: 55.1% ‚úì Plot saved as 'sensor_filtering.png'

Welcome to the Physical AI & Humanoid Robotics text-book - your comprehensive guide to learning Physical AI, humanoid robotics, robot manipulation, locomotion, perception, and control through interactive tutorials, hands-on labs, and structured content.
documents.s: Welcome to Physical AI & Humanoid Robotics text-book

documents.t: This platform provides a structured approach to learning Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics, covering fundamental concepts to advanced techniques. Each chapter is designed with: üìö Clear Learning Objectives - Know exactly what you'll master üí° Concepts & Diagrams - Visual explanations with Mermaid diagrams üíª Tested Code Examples - Working robotics code you can run and modify üî¨ Hands-On Labs - Interactive robotics exercises with step-by-step guidance ‚ö†Ô∏è Common Pitfalls - Learn from common mistakes in robotics üìù Exercises - Practice problems at beginner, intermediate, and advanced levels ‚úÖ Quizzes - Test your understanding of robotics concepts ‚ùì FAQs - Quick answers to common robotics questions
Ready to begin your Physical AI and Humanoid Robotics learning journey? Start with Chapter 1: Introduction to AI.
Learn in your preferred language! Switch between English and Urdu using the language selector in the top navigation.
Toggle between light and dark themes for comfortable reading at any time.
Use the search bar to quickly find topics, concepts, and answers across all chapters.

This platform is built with Docusaurus, a modern static site generator optimized for documentation. It's designed to provide: Fast page loads Responsive design for all devices Accessible content SEO-optimized pages Ready to start learning? Navigate to the first chapter using the sidebar or click the button below. Start Learning ‚Üí
This guide walks you through deploying your AI Textbook Platform to GitHub Pages with automated CI/CD using GitHub Actions.
GitHub account Git installed locally Repository pushed to GitHub GitHub Pages enabled in repository settings

Edit docusaurus.config.js and replace the placeholder values: // Replace these values with your actual GitHub details url: 'https://YOUR-GITHUB-USERNAME.github.io', baseUrl: '/YOUR-REPO-NAME/', organizationName: 'YOUR-GITHUB-USERNAME', projectName: 'YOUR-REPO-NAME', Example: url: 'https://johndoe.github.io', baseUrl: '/ai-book/', organizationName: 'johndoe', projectName: 'ai-book',
documents.s: Step 1: Update Configuration with Your GitHub Details

documents.t: Go to GitHub and sign in Click the "+" icon ‚Üí "New repository" Repository name: ai-book (or your preferred name) Description: "AI Textbook Platform - Interactive learning with Docusaurus" Visibility: Public (required for free GitHub Pages) Do NOT initialize with README, .gitignore, or license (we already have these) Click "Create repository"

# Navigate to your project directory cd "C:\Users\HAJI LAPTOP KARACHI\Desktop\ai-book" # Initialize git (if not already done) git init # Add all files git add . # Create initial commit git commit -m "Initial commit: Docusaurus platform with Chapter 1" # Add remote repository (replace with your actual URL) git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/ai-book.git # Push to GitHub git branch -M main git push -u origin main
documents.s: Step 3: Push Your Code to GitHub

documents.t: Go to your repository on GitHub Click Settings tab Scroll down to Pages section (left sidebar) Under "Source": Select: Deploy from a branch Branch: gh-pages Folder: / (root) Click Save

Go to the Actions tab in your repository You should see a workflow run called "Deploy to GitHub Pages" Click on it to see the progress Wait for the workflow to complete (usually 2-5 minutes) Once complete, visit: https://YOUR-USERNAME.github.io/ai-book/

The GitHub Actions workflow (.github/workflows/deploy.yml) automatically: Triggers on every push to the main branch Checks out your code Sets up Node.js 18 Installs dependencies with npm ci Builds the site with npm run build Deploys to the gh-pages branch GitHub Pages serves the site from gh-pages branch

Via GitHub Actions: Go to Actions tab View recent workflow runs Green checkmark = successful deployment Red X = failed deployment (click to see logs) Via GitHub Pages: Go to Settings ‚Üí Pages See "Your site is live at..." message Click the URL to visit your site
Commit & Push: Instant GitHub Actions Build: 2-3 minutes GitHub Pages Update: 1-2 minutes Total: ~5 minutes from push to live site
Cause: Dependency installation issues Solution: Delete package-lock.json locally Run npm install to regenerate it Commit and push the new package-lock.json
documents.s: Issue 1: Workflow Fails with "npm ci" Error

documents.t: Cause: Incorrect baseUrl in configuration Solution: Check docusaurus.config.js: baseUrl: '/ai-book/', // Must match repository name Ensure it ends with / Commit, push, and wait for redeployment
Cause: Repository settings not configured Solution: Go to Settings ‚Üí Pages Select source: "Deploy from a branch" Select branch: gh-pages Save and wait for deployment
Cause: Workflow file not in correct location Solution: Verify file exists at: .github/workflows/deploy.yml Check file is committed and pushed Verify branch name is main (not master)
Cause: GitHub Pages cache Solution: Wait 5-10 minutes for cache to clear Hard refresh browser (Ctrl+Shift+R) Try incognito/private browsing mode
documents.s: Issue 5: Build Succeeds but Site Doesn't Update

documents.t: Create static/CNAME with your domain: yourdomain.com

Add these DNS records with your domain provider: For apex domain (yourdomain.com): A @ 185.199.108.153 A @ 185.199.109.153 A @ 185.199.110.153 A @ 185.199.111.153 For subdomain (www.yourdomain.com): CNAME www YOUR-USERNAME.github.io
Go to Settings ‚Üí Pages Check "Enforce HTTPS" Wait for SSL certificate to provision (can take up to 24 hours)

If you prefer manual deployment without GitHub Actions: # Set your GitHub username GIT_USER=YOUR-USERNAME npm run deploy This will: Build the site Push to gh-pages branch Trigger GitHub Pages deployment

Before deploying, verify: docusaurus.config.js has correct URL and baseUrl All content files are committed package.json and package-lock.json are committed .github/workflows/deploy.yml exists and is committed Repository is public (for free GitHub Pages) No sensitive data in code (check .gitignore) After deploying, verify: GitHub Actions workflow completes successfully Site is accessible at GitHub Pages URL All pages load without 404 errors Navigation works correctly Search functionality works Mermaid diagrams render Responsive design works on mobile Dark mode toggle works

Once set up, every push to main automatically deploys: # Make changes to content vim docs/chapters/chapter-02/index.md # Commit changes git add . git commit -m "Add Chapter 2: Machine Learning" # Push to GitHub (triggers automatic deployment) git push origin main # Wait 5 minutes, then visit your site to see updates

Test locally first: Always run npm start and verify changes before pushing Use feature branches: Create branches for major changes, merge to main when ready Write clear commit messages: Helps track what changed in each deployment Monitor Actions tab: Check for failed deployments and fix issues promptly Keep dependencies updated: Regularly update packages for security and features
The workflow already includes npm caching: - name: Setup Node.js uses: actions/setup-node@v4 with: node-version: 18 cache: npm # Caches node_modules for faster builds
Keep dependencies minimal Use npm ci instead of npm install (faster, more reliable) Enable GitHub Actions caching
Check Actions tab for build duration Target: <3 minutes for typical builds If builds are slow, review dependencies and build process

Never commit secrets: Use GitHub Secrets for sensitive data Review dependencies: Regularly audit for vulnerabilities Use HTTPS: Always enable "Enforce HTTPS" in GitHub Pages settings Keep repository public: Required for free GitHub Pages (or upgrade to Pro) Review workflow permissions: Workflow has contents: write permission (required for deployment)

GitHub Pages Docs: https://docs.github.com/en/pages GitHub Actions Docs: https://docs.github.com/en/actions Docusaurus Deployment: https://docusaurus.io/docs/deployment Ready to deploy? Follow the steps above to get your AI Textbook Platform live on GitHub Pages!
